publicationStmt.idno: Source copy consulted: Oxford, Corpus Christi College, Oxford, MS 201

head.note:
Rubbing and cropping have rendered some text at the top of the page illegible. The interior characters in Pers are virtually illegible because of rubbing, and the end of Plowman has been lost to cropping. The following is legible:
Incipit Pers Ã¾e Plowman
.No. 1668. 201. D.3.10.
Piers the : Plowman.
The shelfmark "D.3.10." is written in a darker ink in a modern hand. Other matter, perhaps a quotation of the first line (?), has been scraped and is illegible.

lg.l: AlF.1.1: The ornamental capital is blue with red and white flourishes. Set in gold foil is an image of the sleeping dreamer with his head in his left hand and an image of a walled city beneath his feet. He wears three-fingered laborer's gloves, perhaps suggesting that the illustrator has conflated dreamer and plowman.F.1.1: All other B manuscripts begin "In a somer seson . . . ." Though certainty is not possible, the similar ornamental capital in the Ushaw College fragment written in the same workshop suggests that this lection is intended to take advantage of the workman's skill, since an <A> offers more scope for the illustration than an <I>. The change in the text is, in this instance, more probably the work of the immediate scribe than of the F-Redactor. in somer sesoun / whan softe was the sunne
I shoop me in-to shrowdes / as y sheep[a] sheep wereF.1.2: F omits the following line from Bx: "In habite as an heremite vnholy of werkes."
& wente wyde in . Ã¾is world / wondres to here
& on May[a] May morwe / on malverne hillis
By-fel me a feerly / as fayrye me thowhte
I was wery of wandrynge / & wente me to reste
Vpon a brood banke / be a boorne syde
& as y lay & lenede / & lokede on Ã¾e wawys
I slumbrede in-to slepyng / it swyÈede so merye
Ãan gan y to meetyn / a mervelous sweuene
Ãat y was in a wyldernesse / wiste y neuere where
I beheld in-to Est[Ã¾e] Est / an heyÈ to Ã¾e sunne
I seyÈ a tour on a tuft / tryally y-tymbryd
& a deep dale be-nethe / a dongoun Ã¾er-Inne
With depe dychis & derke / & dredful to syghte
& a fayr feeld ful of folk / y fond Ã¾ere be-twene
Of alle manere of men / Ã¾e mene & Ã¾e ryche
Wyrkynge & wandrynge / as this world askeÃ¾
Summe pitte hem-selue to plowh / & pleyede seldyn
& in settynge & sowynge / Ã¾ey swonken ful harde
& summe pitte hem to pride / & a-parayled hem Ã¾er-after
In contynances of clothynge / kemen fele dysgysydF.1.22: An otiose curl appears over the <g>.
& wonnen Ã¾at Ã¾ese wastoures / with glotenye dystroyenF.1.23: This line appears after F1.20 in Bx.
In prayerys & in penaunces / pitte hem-selue manye
For Ã¾e love of oure lord / Ã¾ei lyvedyn ful streyte
In hope to have to hyre ï ¡ heuyn-ryche blysse
As Ankrys & hermytys / Ã¾at holde hem-selue in sellys
& coueyte nowht in cuntres / to kayren a-bowte
For noF.1.29: An otiose curl appears over the <n>. likorous lyflode / here lykame to plese
& summe chesen chaffare / to cheven Ã¾e bettre
As it semeÃ¾ to oure syght / Ã¾at swiche men thryvyn
& summe merthis to makeF.1.32: F omits the b-verse "as Mynstralles konneth" and the following a-verse: "And geten gold with hire glee." / synneles y leve
But Iaperis & Iangeleris / ben Iudas childryn
Ãei feynen hem fantesyes / & folis hem maken
& welden wit at wille / to worche what Ã¾ei sholde
What Poul precheÃ¾ of hem / y wil not preue it heereF.1.36: F omits the following line from Bx: "Qui loquitur turpiloquium is luciferes hyne."
BoÃ¾e bidderis & beggeris / faste a-bowtyn wentynF.1.37: F omits the following line from Bx: "WiÃ¾ hire bely and hire bagge of breed ful ycrammed."

& fele fayted for here foode / & fowtyn at Ã¾e aleF.1.38: A late seventeenth- or early eighteenth-century Corpus Christi College librarian supplied the following inscription at the bottom of the page: Liber C.C.C Oxon.
Ex dono Gulielmi Fulman A. M. hujus Collegii quondam Socii.William Fulman (1632-1688), born Penshurst, Kent, in November, 1632, became a scholar at Corpus Christi College, Oxford, in 1647, was expelled in 1648 by Parliamentarians, and at the restoration in 1660 was created M.A. and Fellow of the college. He remained in college until 1669 when he took a living in Gloucestershire, where he died of a fever in 1688. See the Dictionary of National Biography, eds. Leslie Stephen and Sidney Lee (Oxford: Oxford U P, 1917): 7.767-68.
& god woot with glotenye / Ã¾ey goon to-gydre to bedde
& rysen vp / with rubawdye / Ã¾o roberis knavis
& sleep & sory slewthe / seweth hem euere
Â¶ Pylgrymes & palmeris / pyghtyn hem to-gydre
To seken seynt Iemes / & seyntis in Rome
& wentyn forÃ¾ / on here way / with fele wyse talis

& haddyn leve / for to lyÈen / al here lyve afterF.1.45: F lacks the following lines attested by beta family manuscripts:
I seiÈ somme Ã¾at seiden Ã¾ei hadde ysouÈt Seintes
To ech a tale Ã¾at Ã¾ei tolde hire tonge was tempred to lye
Moore Ã¾an to seye sooÃ¾ it semed bi hire speche
Heremytes on an heep with hoked staues
Wenten to walsyngham and hire wenches after.
& grete longe lobyes / Ã¾at looÃ¾ weryn to swynke
Clothid hem in copis / to be knowe fram oÃ¾ere
& shoop hem lyk hermytis / here ese for to kacche
/ [Â¶] I fond Ã¾ere of Ã¾e freris / alle Ã¾e fowre ordris
Ãat precheden Ã¾e peple / for profyÈt of hem-selue
& gloseden Ã¾e gospel / as hem-selue lykede
For coueytyse of copis / Ã¾ei construe as Ã¾ei wille
Fele of Ã¾e Maystris / may cloÃ¾e hem at lykyng
For here mone & marchaundyse / marchyn to-gydre
For sytthe Charite is chapman / & cheef to shryve lordis
Fele ferlijs have ben falle / in a fewe Èeeris
& but holy chirche & they / holde bettre to-gydre
Ãe mooste myschef on moolde / ys mountynge faste
Â¶ There prechede a pardoner / as he a preest where
& browhte forÃ¾ a bulle / with bysshopis selys
& seyde Ã¾at hym-selue / myghte a-soyle hem alle
Of false oÃ¾is & fastyngis / & fele avowys brokene
& lewide men belevid hem wel / & lykeden hise woordis
& kemen vp knelynge / & kessede his bulle
& he blessid hem with his brevet / & blerede here eyÈen
& lawhte[r]awhte with his ragman / ryngis & brochis
& Ã¾orghÈ Ã¾e seelis on Ã¾e selk / syluer gret plente These two lines appear only in F.
With wheche his konkebyne at hom / is klad ful klene
& Ã¾us men gyven here gold / glotonys to kepe
& be-leven on Ã¾o loselis / Ã¾at leccherye hawnten
But where Ã¾e blessynge bisshop / worÃ¾ boÃ¾e his eryn
His seel sholde not be sent / to disseyve Ã¾e peple
But itit [is] not be Ã¾e bisshop / Ã¾at so Ã¾e boy precheÃ¾
But Ã¾e parsoun er Ã¾e preest / ys cawse of Ã¾e gilteF.1.74: This line appears only in F.
For Ã¾e prest & Ã¾e pardoner / shulle departen Ã¾e syluerF.1.75: The <l> was inserted after the word was initially written, probably by the original scribe.

F.1.76: An early scribe has written an abbreviation for nota in the left margin. Note that the curious mark beneath it is repeated again on passus 27r, again in connection with a nota abbreviation. Ãat Ã¾e pore men of Ã¾e parschÈ ï ¡ sholde have if Ã¾ey nere

Â¶ Bothe parsonys & vikerysF.1.77: F's a-verse is unique. Beta witnesses have "Persons and parisshe preestes." In the absence of R, it is not possible to identify the source of the error. / pleynede to Ã¾e bisshop
Ãat here parschenys where pore / sitthe Ã¾e pestylence tyme
To have lycence & leve / at loondenn to dwellyn.
& syngyn Ã¾ere for Symony / for siluer ys swete.

BoÃ¾e Maystris & Bisshopis / & bacheleres & doctoris.F.1.81: F's reading is unique. Beta witnesses have "Bisshopes and Bachelers boÃ¾e maistres and doctours." In the absence of R, it is not possible to identify the source of the error.
Ãat have cure vndir crist / & konynge to knowe.
& chargeF.1.83: F's charge is unique. Beta witnesses have signe. Ã¾at Ã¾ei sholden at hom / shryvyn here parsshenis.
& prechen & praye for hem ï ¡ & Ã¾e poore leene & feede.
& nowht lyÈn in Londenn / in Lentene & ellys.
Â¶ & summe seruyn Ã¾e kyng / & his syluer tellyn.
In Ã¾e cheker & in Ã¾e Chauncery / to chalange hise dettes.
Of wardis / & of warde-motis / of wayvis & strayes.
& summe be Clerkis of Ã¾e kyngys bench / Ã¾e cuntre to shende.F.1.89: This line appears only in F in the B textual tradition. Cf. Kane, A Prol.95.
& summe seruyn as seruauntys / Lordys & ladijs.
& in Ã¾e stede oso[f] styward / Ã¾ey Iuggyn & demen.F.1.91: F's b-verse is unique. Beta witnesses have "sitten and demen."
But here mase ne matynys / ne manye of here oures.

Be not salysbery hews / here Ordynal so tellyÃ¾.F.1.93: This line in F replaces two in Bx:
Arn doon vndeuoutliche drede is at Ã¾e laste
Lest crist in consistorie acorse ful manye.
/ [Â¶] I parceyvede of Ã¾at power / Ã¾at Peter hadde to kepe
To byÈnde & vnbyÈnde / as Ã¾e book telliÃ¾.
How he lefte it with love / as oure lord hym hyghte.
A-mongys foure vertues / most vertuous of hevene.

Ãere crist ys in hys kyngdomm / to close & to shette.
& to opene it to hem / & heuene blysse hem shewe.
& Ã¾e Cardynalis at Ã¾e court / of hem kawtyn name.

To haue Ã¾e Powher / Ã¾at peter hadde / Inpugne y nylle.

For-Ã¾y ï ¡ y can / & can not ï ¡ of Ã¾e cowrt carpyn more.

& Ã¾e myght of hyse comonys / maden hym to regne.

Ãey casten Ã¾atF.1.111: The scribe first wrote Ã¾e and corrected it to Ã¾t. Ã¾e comonys / sholde fyÈnde hem-selue.F.1.111: An otiose curl appears above the second <e> in hemselue.

& for profyÈt of Ã¾e peple / plowhmen Ã¾ey made.

Schopen lawe / be lewte / ech lyf to knowe his owe.
Â¶ Ãanne lookede a lunatyk / a lene Ã¾yng with-alle.
He gan knele to Ã¾e kyng / & clergyaly seyde.
Cryst kepe Ã¾e sire kyng / & Ã¾yn kyngdom ryche.
& levele[n]e Ã¾e / so lede Ã¾yn lond / so lewhte Ã¾e a-lowe.
& for Ã¾yn ryght-ful rewlyng / Ã¾ou be rewardid in heuene.

& a-non fram Ã¾e hevene on heyÈ / com doun an Angyle.F.1.122: F's line is unique. Bx has "And siÃ¾en in Ã¾e Eyr an heiÈ an Aungel of heuene." The scribe neglected to supply red touches on the beginning letters of lines and on highlighted words on folios 2v-3r. He sometimes failed throughout the manuscript to supply colored parasigns, though he marked the place for each with a light solidus.
& lowhde spak in Latyn / for lewede men ne sholde.
Ianglyn ne Iuggen hym / ne Iustefye hym with mowÃ¾e.
But suffren & seruyn / softly / for-Ã¾y ï ¡ seyde Ã¾e angil.

hi.hi: um rex sum princeps . neutrum fortasse deinceps.
qui iura regis . cristi specialia legis[r]egis.
oc quod agas melius . iustus es esto pius.

udum visF.1.129: Alpha reads vis. All beta family manuscripts read ius with version C. a te . vestireF.1.129: Alpha is responsible for vestire, though the reading is shared by H. Beta witnesses have vestiri. vult pietate.
valia vis metere . talia grana sere.
i visF.1.131: RFH read vis against ius in all other manuscripts. nudatur . nudo de iure metatur.
i seritur pietas . de pietate metas.

lg.l: / [Â¶] Thanne grevid hym a Goliardes / a glotoun of woordys.
& to Ã¾e Angel on hey ï ¡ he answerede soone.

hi.hi: um rex a regere . dicatur nomen habere
omen habet sine re . nisi studet iura tenere.

lg.l: / [Â¶] Thanne cryeden alle Ã¾e comonys / with o voys a tonysat onys.F.1.137: Alpha omits the following line attested by beta witnesses: "To Ã¾e kynges counseil construe whoso wolde."

hi.hi: recepta regis . sunt nobis uincula legis.

lg.l: / [Â¶] With Ã¾at kemenF.1.139: F's kemen is unique. Bx has ran Ã¾er. a rowhte / of Ratonys manye.
& Manye Mees with hem / moo Ã¾anne a Ã¾owsande

For a Cat in Ã¾e court / cam whan hire[hym] lykede.
& ouer-leep hem lyghtly / & lawht hem at wylle.
& pleyeÃ¾ with vs apertly / & posseÃ¾ vs a-bowhte.
& for drede of deeÃ¾ / we ne dore not wel looken.
& if we gruccheF.1.146: Alpha is responsible for the omission of of after grucche. F alone has wille in place of gamen. his wille / he wil greve vs sore.
& cracche vs / & clawe vs / & in his cloche vs holde.
Ãat we loÃ¾yn oure lyf / er he leete vs passen.
/ [Â¶] But myghte we be ony wit / hys wille with-stonde.
We weryn lordys on lofte / & lyven in gret ese.
/ [Â¶] Ãanne a Ratoun of renoun / moost renable of tunge.
Seyde a resonable resounF.1.152: F's a-verse is unique. Bx has "Seide for a souereyn." / & helplych to hem alle.F.1.152: Alpha is responsible for "hem alle." Beta witnesses have "to hymselue."
I have herd ofF.1.153: F's "herd of" is unique. Beta witnesses have "yseyen." seggis quod he ï ¡ in Ã¾e Cyte of Lundoun.
Ãat men beryn bryghte byÈes / a-bowtyn here nekkys.
& summe Coleres of crafty werk / vn-cowpled Ã¾ey walke.
BoÃ¾e in wareyn & in waast / where hem best lykeÃ¾.
& oÃ¾ire-whylys ellys-where / as weyÈes me telle.F.1.157: F has revised the line, changing the alliterative pattern. Bx has "And ouÃ¾er-while Ã¾ei arn elliswhere as I here telle."
Where Ã¾ere a belle on here beyÈe / by IesusF.1.158: Alpha is responsible for Iesus. Beta witnesses have Iesu. as me Ã¾ynkeÃ¾.
Men myghten wetyn / where Ã¾ei wente / & a-wey renne.
Ryght so quod Ã¾e Ratoun / as resoun me sheweth.
It were best to begge a bras belle / or of shyÈnF.1.161: F's shyÈn is unique. Bx has briÈt. syluer.
& knette it on a Coler / for oure Comoune profyÈt

& hange it a-bowte Ã¾e Cattys hals / Ã¾at here hym we mowe.F.1.163: Alpha lacks the following two lines attested by beta witnesses:
Wher he ryt or rest or renneÃ¾ to pleye
And if hym list for to laike Ã¾anne loke we mowen.
& a-peren in his absenseF.1.164: F's addition of vus in the b-verse shows that the revision of Bx's presence to absense was intended. / Ã¾e while vus pleye lykeÃ¾.
& yf he wratthe / to be war / & hise weye shone.
Ãanne alle Ã¾eF.1.166: Alpha is responsible for Ã¾e. Beta witnesses have Ã¾is. rowhte of Ratonys / to Ã¾is resoun assentid.
But whanne Ã¾e belle was bowht / & on Ã¾e byÈe hanged.
Ãere was no ratoun / of Ã¾at rowhte / for Ã¾e Rewhme of Fraunce.
Ãat durste a bownde Ã¾at bond / a-bowte Ã¾e Cattys nekke.
Ne honge yt a-bowte hisF.1.170: Alpha and C have his. Beta witnesses have Ã¾e cattes. hals / al Ingelond to wynne.
But helden hem-selue vn-hardy / & al here conseyl feble.
& al here labour was loost / & here large costes.
/ [Â¶] Thanne a Mows / Ã¾at mychil good / cowhde / as me thowhte.
Strook forÃ¾ sternely / & stood be-fore hem alle.
& to Ã¾e rowhte of ratonys / he reersyde Ã¾ese wordys.
/ [Â¶] They we haddyn kyllyd Ã¾at Cat / Èyt sholde Ã¾ere come a-noÃ¾ir.
& kacche vus & oure kyÈnde / whan we kroule a-bowte.
For-Ã¾y ï ¡ by my conseyl / to soffre Ã¾e Cat a-worthe.F.1.178: F's line is unique. Bx has "ForÃ¾i I counseille al Ã¾e commune to late Ã¾e cat worÃ¾e."
& no bacheler be so bold / Ã¾e belle hym to shewe.F.1.179: See Kane-Donaldson, 176, for their editorial reasoning on re-ordering this passage.
For y herde myn syre seyn / is sevene Èeer y-passed.
Ãere Ã¾e Cat ys kytoun / Ã¾e court ys elenge.
Ãat witnessiÃ¾ holy wryt / who-so wille it rede.

hi.hi: e terre . ubi puer rex est.

l.note: F.1.183: A cross is written in the right margin beside this line in an ink like that used by the original scribe.

lg.l: There may no renke haue reste / for rattys on nyghtis.
/ [Â¶] For whilis he cacchiÃ¾ conyes / he coueyteÃ¾ not oure bowkys.F.1.185: bowkys, "bodies, carcasses."
But fediÃ¾ hym with fenysoun / defame we hym neuere.
For bettre ys a lytil los / Ã¾an a long sorwe.
Ãe Maase ï ¡ a-mong vs alle / Ã¾ey we mysse a shrewe.
For manye mennys malt ellis / we myÈs wille distroye.
& also ellis Èee ratonys / wolde renden renkes clothys.F.1.190: F's reading is unique. Bx reads "And also ye route of Ratons rende mennes cloÃ¾es." H also omits "route of."
Ne were Ã¾e cat of Ã¾e court / Ã¾at can a-mong Èow lepe.
For hadde Èe ratonysF.1.192: Alpha reads ratonys, a reading in which it is joined by GH and the C version. Beta manuscripts have rattes. Èoure wille / Èee cowhde not rewle Èour-selue.
I sey Ã¾isF.1.193: Alpha is responsible for the direct object. R has it. Beta manuscripts lack an object. for my-selue quod Ã¾e Mous / & see so mychil after.
Shal neuere Cat ne kytoun / by myn conseyl be grevid.
Ne carpynge of his coler / coste me neuere after.
& Ã¾owh it costeF.1.196: Alpha and G lack beta's hadde before coste. me catel / by-knowe itF.1.196: An otiose curl appears above the <t>. y nylle.
But suffre as summe oÃ¾ire do / to slen what hym lykeÃ¾.
Cowpled / & vncowplyd / to cacche what he wille.
& euery wyÈs Mows y warne / to wacche wel hym-selue.
/ [Â¶] What Ã¾is Metelys meneÃ¾ / Èee men / Ã¾at been here-Inne.
I ne dar dyvyne it Èow / be dere god in hevene.
/ [Â¶] Èit hovede Ã¾ere an hundred / in howfes on Molde.F.1.202: The scribe was perhaps confused by howfes, "coifs." Bx reads "in howues of selk."
Sergawntys Ã¾ey semeden / Ã¾at seruede at Ã¾e barre.
Pleteden for Ã¾e peny / & pownded Ã¾e lawe.
& nowht for oure lordys love / vn-lose here lyppe onys.
Ãou myghtyst bettre meten myst / on Maluerne hellys ï ¡

Ãan getyn a Mum of here mowht / erF.1.207: Alpha is responsible for er. Beta manuscripts have til or but. mone be shewyd.F.1.207: F omits the following line from Bx: "Barons and burgeis and bondemen als."
Â¶ I seyÈ in Ã¾is a-semble / as Èee shulle here after.
BoÃ¾e Bakerys / & Brewsteres / & Bocherys manye.
& also wolle websterys / & webberys of Lynene.
& Tayloures & Tynkeres / & tollerys of Market.
& Masonys & Mynowrys / & manye oÃ¾ire craftys.
Of alleF.1.213: Alpha lacks beta's kynne before lyvynge. lyvynge laborerys / lope Ã¾ere furthÈ summe.
As dykerys & delueres / Ã¾at doon here dedes ylle.
& dryve furthÈ Ã¾e fayre day / with deu vous saue dame Emme.
/ [Â¶] Ãere wheren kene Cokys knavis / criÈeden / hote pyes hote ï ¡
Goode fatte gryÈs & gees / gowego we dyghne . gowego we.
/ [Â¶] & Ã¾e Tauernerys vn-tyl hem / tolledyn Ã¾e same.
With good fyÈn MaluesynF.1.219: F alone has this reading. Bx reads "Whit wyn of Oseye." Malvesie is a sweet Greek wine from Napoli di Malvasia. / or wyn of Gaskoyne.
Or Rochel or RomeneyF.1.220: F's a-verse is unique. Bx reads "Of Ã¾e Ryn and of Ã¾e Rochel." / Ã¾e roost to diffyÈe.
